author: @berryzem
text:
Olay I cannot thank you enough for this video. I'm a mixed Palestinian American and would like to talk a bit about my family's experience if that's okay:

My great grandparents and grandfather on my dad's side lived in Jaffa. They owned farmland. Acres of orange and olive trees. They had a house on the shore and would have cookouts/picnics on the weekend. It's a beautiful place (think a type of port city people dream of vacationing to) They lost everything when the occupation happened in '48 and my dad grew up and lived in a tiny garage in Jerusalem (the house it was attached to was owned by some relatives who offered it up for my displaced relatives to stay) with his 5 brothers, parents, grandparents, and a couple of aunts/uncles. My dad has trauma that is just...unfathomable to even talk about growing up in such extreme poverty. He literally worked as a child to help provide for the family because my grandfather was only earning up to $20 a month to feed 8 people. When my dad was 20, he had to go to Jordan to get a passport to even come to this country because he had no country. Palestine isn't even considered a country. That's just scratching the surface.

After becoming a US citizen, my dad refused to pay taxes because he knew where the government sent that tax money. How could he send money to the people who were the very reason his family suffered and are to this day still suffering so much?
He almost went to jail after being audited by you know who. My mom wasn't about to let that happen so she often would work 60-80 hour weeks to help pay that off. Didn't exactly do me and my siblings many favors having our parents working so hard all the time and constantly burnt out, but we made it. I, as a child at the time, couldn't understand it. Now I do. You can imagine how pissed I was when that report came out the previous president paid less than $800 in taxes in that year meanwhile my family had to pay tens of thousands of dollars in the early 2000s. 

I definitely can say with absolute certainty that growing up in this country has felt like being an unwilling participant of a life-long gaslighting experiment. Truthfully, I wasn't even expecting a portion of the support that has been outpouring over the world for Palestine when I first heard about what began in October. You just kind of...get used to people just sweeping it under the rug when the news is loud and clear where their support lies, you know? Growing up, I didn't have the resources like the internet to find out that Malcom X, the Black Panthers,  Nelson Mandela, and so many more people supported Palestine (I grew up in a mid-low income neighborhood. Decent internet wasn't even available to me until 2010) so it felt so...isolating. I've never been so happy to have been proven wrong over the years.

From the bottom of my heart, I thank you. Thank you for taking the time and the risk to think of us (I know you had another video about voting you wanted to make and I look forward to watching that too and the video about the Congo) and thank you for your support. I'm sending lots of love your way ‚ô•

author: @TearXstar
text:
This is a fantastic video, thank you for using your platform to bring awareness on whats happening. One problem i'm having though; I went to look for the full Malcom X speech, "The Palestinian struggle is not just a cry for justice, it's a blistering battle for the most fundamental human rights," from 1964, but I can't seem to find the original speech anywhere, and every article including it seems to be only a month old and referencing the tiktok.

A few places are claiming it to be AI generated. One youtube channel has a video called "The Viral Malcom X Speech on Palestine is not real" and seems to debunk it in the description, noting inconsistencies with his use of language and historical dates, and claiming to have confirmed that the creator wrote it themselves and used AI to mimic Malcom X, falsely attributing it to an article Malcom X wrote called "Zionist Logic." The problem is that they don't identify who the original creator is and comments are off so I can't ask them. 

I know for certain Malcom X has spoken about and been to Palestine, but I'm not sure if this speech was real? If anyone can help me track down the original speech that'd be wonderful!!

author: @NaderNabilart
text:
I've been following Olay for a while and completely understand the hesitation every marginalized voice have battled with before talking about Palestine. Building bridges between our common struggles will eventually knock down the walls that keep us segregated and far from creating a critical mass movement against our oppressors.
Been following closely Black American activism ever since Ferguson 2014 and felt the tectonic shift after George Floyd in 2020 suddenly everyone in Arab communities in the middle east and in diaspora are strongly vocal about Black liberation and racism in the West. Probably read hundreds of articles and posts by regular people and intellectuals, but that's not nearly enough, we need to be more vocal, create common spaces and discussions, on the ground protesting, marching, doing everything we could for our brothers.
Essential part of this 75-year struggle for Palestinian liberation will be about educating and informing, rooting out antisemitism and racism generally and combating false narratives.

Btw I'm Egyptian and Olay introduced me and lots of my friends here to a whole new spectrum of Black activists and voices and their struggles seem a lot like ours, we can learn a lot from each other.
All love to Olay from Egypt ‚ù§‚ù§

text: I'm with Dr Umar on this one. I'm from the country Dr Umar mentioned. The events in Gaza coincided with the fact that for the first time in 3 decades my country was fighting back against an American backed unrest that saw the death of more than 10 Million Congolese people. In color, in full HD but in silence. I have never seen an Israeli, a Palestinian or even a Ukrainian cry for my people or denounce what happened to them..I'm not saying that I want y'all to do the same and worry about the Congo. I'm saying we have our own problems to worry about. The best I could contribute in what's happening In Palestine is that if it looks, walks and smells like  genocide. Don't let them gaslight you into telling you otherwise. They are getting exterminated. Other than that I believe American sensationalism makes us think that we need to have a loud opinion on everything and get involved in everything. I refuse to be the hero of other people's problems while we been fighting our own by our lonesome for centuries.

replies.author: @pbjmochi8400
replies.text:
It may SEEM hopeless, but there is hope. There always is. I've seen more support in protests from around the world than ever before. Yes, people are being censored for speaking out, but they're still speaking out. I will continue to speak out.

Pay attention to what's going on, but pay attention to your mental health, too! Genocide is incomprehensible to the human brain by design. It normalizes death to the point of learned helplessness. Do not give in. Remember: look for the helpers. Look for those who resist injustice. Look for those who find joy in spite of everything.*

*To clarify: this isn't advocating for inspiration porn. That's self-centered and gross. What I AM advocating for is understanding that kindness and resistance is just as human as our capacity for cruelty, if not moreso. Hatred is learned. It can and should be unlearned.

author: @Jammoud
text:
God thank you so much for this. My family‚Äôs first gen from lebanon moved to Tennessee at a young age man. Growing up has been a constant disillusionment of america - laden with hypocrisy and  islamophobia. I always felt weak feeling that it was so hard being arab/muslim in the USA - but given the uptick in awareness and vids like this make me feel sane and put words to feelings i‚Äôve felt my whole life.

what i realized is that the average white american has no original opinions - faux performative caring but will always default to ideas and subconscious racist beliefs the minute it threatens their feeling of entitled status as the normal, salient race. This uptick in palestinian erasure has revealed to me who in my life truly do and don‚Äôt get it - most white people think they get it and are being open minded, but rarely actually peek beneath the surface of their conditioning to see the true nature of what is going on. The arab has been a convenient boogey man for all of western society, the arab and ‚Äúthe orient‚Äù have and will always be a great device for western people to justify hatred of a group and assurance of their own values. The average american wants to think that they‚Äôre agents in their decision making and have moral world views, but they remain under the thumb of media and ideologies that trigger their emotions and create a false sense of threatening of their position as the the dominant race. 

nothing scares the dominant people than the oppressed group becoming aware and empowered

author: @serenity6831
text:
Im so glad you touched on the inportance of black people supporting Palestine. Its not that theres *no* antiblackness in Palestine (and not just from Israeli occupants), bc its everywhere due to the insiduousness of antiblackness itself. Its that when one of us is violently oppressed, we all are. Black people have an extremely fine tuning for oppression wherever it lies, bc we know it well here. This is our fight as well (along with the colonized people of Congo, Sudan, etc). 

I do wish we knew more about the Congolese ppl's plight because it is the same violent genocide, but its often taken a backseat to whats going on in Palestine, and we all know why.

text: Another golden video!! author: @kynetx
text:
Thanks for this. While I appreciate the "no one is free till we're all free" philosophy, I can't get behind the attitude of "where were you when I needed help?".
I saw it with some anti-racist creators expressing glee over Mexican oppression in the states, lumping them in with anti-communist Cuban far-right voters. "Where were the Latinos/Chicanos when black people were asking for help?". They were probably in Mexico trying to figure out how to feed their families, most likely.
Its POC vs US foreign and domestic policy. We got no time for resentment and scorekeeping.

author: @f.d.5173
text: So I'm black (Haitian to be specific) and recently started to convert to Judaism. I have a lot of Jewish friends but had to cut a few out of my life because they didn't like me not blindly supporting Israel. I've always supported Palestine but never this loudly before. I just graduated college and it was crazy to see how Israel is active in our universities, let alone affecting job security. But I think now's as good a time as ever to lean into socialism for each other if capitalists don't want us speaking out against their sate-sanctioned brutalization of indigenous people.

author: @dariamorgendorffer592
text:
im at 18:50 wow really resonated with me alot when you spoke about your dad
my dad is palestinian and since 2020 (back story: was born and raised in UAE but i left the country 5 years ago and my family still live there and 2020 was the year UAE signed a deal with Israel) he begged me not to talk about palestine while we're on the phone in fear of getting deported to palestine since alot of people were either jailed or deported when they stood with palestine in that country :c
even when he came to visit me, he put all our devices in another room before we dove into the subject, but now since the whole world is finally speaking up and we talk on discord (not under america's surveillance) he's not as scared as before, we talk almost everyday and you have no idea how liberated we feel now, i love my dad so much and he sacrificed so much for us, i wish he didnt have to sacrifice leaving his home for us and i wish he lives long enough to be able to retire back in palestine but i think he's lost all hope on that dream :c
(thank you so much for making this video, imma go back and continue watching <33)
